Potato___healthy.description: The potato plant is healthy and free from diseases.
treatment: No action required.
Follow standard care practices like regular watering and fertilization.
prevention: Practice crop rotation to reduce soil-borne diseases.
Use certified disease-free seed potatoes.
Monitor plants for pests and diseases.

Tomato__Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.description: Yellow leaf curl virus is transmitted by whiteflies and causes stunted growth and yellowing of leaves.
treatment: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately.
Control whitefly populations using insecticides or biological controls.
Avoid planting new crops near infected areas.
prevention: Use reflective mulch to repel whiteflies.
Plant virus-resistant tomato varieties.
Monitor and control whitefly populations regularly.

Potato___Late_blight.description: Late blight in potatoes is caused by Phytophthora infestans and can devastate entire crops.
treatment: Destroy severely infected plants to stop the spread.
Use systemic fungicides like metalaxyl or cymoxanil.
Harvest tubers early if possible to prevent rot.
prevention: Plant certified disease-free seed potatoes.
Avoid overhead watering and ensure good drainage.
Inspect plants frequently during wet weather.

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight in potatoes is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani, leading to dark spots on leaves.
treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves.
Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb.
Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce moisture on leaves.
prevention: Plant resistant potato varieties.
Ensure proper spacing between plants for airflow.
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops.
